articles.headline: Recession Fears Abound, but the Fed Chair Bets This Time Is Different
articles.snippet: Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, thinks his central bank can defy history to clinch slower inflation and a soft economic landing.
articles.abstract: Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, thinks his central bank can defy history to clinch slower inflation and a soft economic landing.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve’s push to slow the economy and bring inflation under control is often compared to an airplane descent, one that could end in a soft landing, a bumpy one or an outright crash.

articles.headline: Justice Dept. Intensifying Efforts to Determine if Trump Hid Documents
articles.snippet: Prosecutors investigating the former president’s handling of classified material have issued a wave of new subpoenas and obtained the confidential cooperation of a witness who worked at Mar-a-Lago.
articles.abstract: Prosecutors investigating the former president’s handling of classified material have issued a wave of new subpoenas and obtained the confidential cooperation of a witness who worked at Mar-a-Lago.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors investigating former President Donald J. Trump’s handling of classified documents have obtained the confidential cooperation of a person who has worked for him at Mar-a-Lago, part of an intensifying effort to determine whether Mr. Trump ordered boxes containing sensitive material moved out of a storage room there as the government sought to recover it last year, multiple people familiar with the inquiry said.
articles.byline: By Maggie Haberman, Adam Goldman, Alan Feuer, Ben Protess and Michael S. Schmidt

articles.headline: Smaller Banks Are Scrambling as Share Prices Plunge
articles.snippet: Investors are not convinced that regional banks including PacWest and Western Alliance can remain viable. Some are actively betting on their demise.
articles.abstract: Investors are not convinced that regional banks including PacWest and Western Alliance can remain viable. Some are actively betting on their demise.
articles.lead_paragraph: A cluster of regional banks scrambled on Thursday to convince the public of their financial soundness, even as their stock prices plunged and investors took bets on which might be the next to fall.
articles.byline: By Rob Copeland, Joe Rennison and Matthew Goldstein

articles.headline: 2 Days, 17 Dead, 21 Wounded: Back to Back Massacres Rock Serbia
articles.snippet: A day after Serbia’s first mass shooting in seven years, a second one left the small country in shock and its president called for a radical reduction in gun ownership.
articles.abstract: A day after Serbia’s first mass shooting in seven years, a second one left the small country in shock and its president called for a radical reduction in gun ownership.
articles.lead_paragraph: DUBONA, Serbia — The killer seemed to mark people for death at random. He drove to a halt at a soccer field near a Serbian farming village, where young people were enjoying drinks and music, opened fire with an assault rifle, and sped off. He fired on another group outside a schoolyard.
articles.byline: By Constant Méheut, John Yoon, Joe Orovic and Jenny Gross

articles.headline: U.S. Job Growth Retains Vigor Despite Economic Worries
articles.snippet: Employers added 253,000 jobs in April and unemployment fell to 3.4 percent, but the labor market’s strength complicates the Fed’s inflation fight.
articles.abstract: Employers added 253,000 jobs in April and unemployment fell to 3.4 percent, but the labor market’s strength complicates the Fed’s inflation fight.
articles.lead_paragraph: The labor market is still defying gravity — for now.

articles.headline: Businesses Caught in Cross-Fire as Iran Enforces Hijab Law
articles.snippet: As more Iranian women go without the head scarves mandated by law, efforts by the government to force businesses to promote compliance points to a growing struggle in the months ahead.
articles.abstract: As more Iranian women go without the head scarves mandated by law, efforts by the government to force businesses to promote compliance points to a growing struggle in the months ahead.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the first days of the Iranian New Year holiday in March, the police showed up at a cafe in Tehran with orders to shut it down for two days. The cafe had run afoul of Iranian law by serving women who were not covering their hair with head scarves, they said.
articles.byline: By Vivian Yee and Leily Nikounazar

articles.headline: Living and Breathing on the Front Line of a Toxic Chemical Zone
articles.snippet: As the Biden administration moves to curb health threats caused by toxic chemicals, the debate hits home for families living near petrochemical plants.
articles.abstract: As the Biden administration moves to curb health threats caused by toxic chemicals, the debate hits home for families living near petrochemical plants.
articles.lead_paragraph: Juan López had just returned home from his job supervising the cleaning of giant tanks that hold toxic chemicals produced along the Houston Ship Channel, one of the largest petrochemical complexes in the world.

articles.headline: ‘Only Word for Them Is Heroes’: How 2 Students Rescued Dozens in Sudan
articles.snippet: As feuding generals turned the Sudanese capital into a war zone, two university students navigated a battered Toyota through the chaos and saved at least 60 desperate people.
articles.abstract: As feuding generals turned the Sudanese capital into a war zone, two university students navigated a battered Toyota through the chaos and saved at least 60 desperate people.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the first days of Sudan’s war, the two university students felt helpless.
